titlestmt.subtitle: A Finding Aid to the Burgoyne Diller Papers, 1924-1968, in the Archives of American Art
titlestmt.author: by Jean Fitzgerald

publicationstmt.publisher: Archives of American Art, Smithsonian Institution

profiledesc.creation: Finding aid encoded by Christina Lehman on June 3, 2005

change.item: Finding aid updated from EAD v. 1.0 to v. 2002 by Stephanie Ashley

did.head: Collection Overview

repository.label: Repository:
repository.corpname: Archives of American Art, Smithsonian Institution

did.abstract: The Burgoyne Diller papers measure 1.0 linear feet and date from 1924-1968. The collection documents the abstract painter's career and includes two letters, a notebook, four annotated sketchbooks, art work, and clippings. The collection primarily consists of art work, including hundreds of drawings that document the development of Burgoyne Diller's unique artistic style.

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Born in New York City in 1906, Burgoyne Diller was brought up in Michigan and attended Michigan State College. He returned to New York in 1926 and studied at the Art Students League from 1928 to 1932, with Hans Hofmann. Diller made his first geometrical paintings in the 1930s, which were influenced by the rigid formulas of Piet Mondrian's "pure plastic art." Diller's work evolved into an abstract mode of configurations of lines, angles, and primary colors. Diller was one of the original members of the American Abstract Artists.

Between 1935 and 1941, Diller worked for the New York City Federal Arts Program, Mural Division, Works Progress Administration, eventually becoming Director. During that time, he provided commissions for many of the most advanced artists of the day, including Arshile Gorky and Stuart Davis. In 1945, he became associate professor of art at Brooklyn College. Burgoyne Diller died in 1965.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The Burgoyne Diller papers measure 1.0 linear feet and date from 1924-1968. The collection documents the abstract painter's career and includes two letters, a notebook, four annotated sketchbooks, art work, and clippings. The collection primarily consists of art work, including hundreds of drawings that document the development of Burgoyne Diller's unique artistic style.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The collection is arranged as four series. Series 1 and 4 are arranged chronologically. Series 2 consists of a single dismantled notebook which maintains the creator's original arrangement. Series 3 has been arranged in a numerically consecutive order introduced by the donor, Kenneth W. Prescott. There are gaps in art work's numerical sequences.

list.item: Series 3: Art work, 1924-1964, undated (Box 1-3; OVS 4-9; 33 folders)

relatedmaterial.head: Related Material
relatedmaterial.p: Burgoyne Diller collection of printed material, 1932-1961.

controlaccess.head: Index Terms
controlaccess.p: This collection is indexed in the online catalog of the Archives of American Art under the following index terms. People, families and organizations are listed under "Subjects" when they are the topic of collection contents and under "Names" when they are creators or contributors.

acqinfo.head: Provenance
acqinfo.p: The Burgoyne Diller papers were donated by the Grace Diller estate via William C. LaCrone, executor, in 1992. Some of the papers were donated by the Diller estate via art historian Kenneth W. Prescott, in 4 installments dating 1983-2000.

accessrestrict.head: Restrictions on Access
accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research. Use requires an appointment and is limited to the Washington, D.C. research facility.

userestrict.head: Ownership and Literary Rights
userestrict.p: The Burgoyne Diller papers are owned by the Archives of American Art, Smithsonian Institution. Literary rights as possessed by the donor have been dedicated to public use for research, study, and scholarship. The collection is subject to all copyright laws.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Burgoyne Diller papers, 1924-1968. Archives of American Art, Smithsonian Institution.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: The collection was processed by Jean Fitzgerald in October 2002.

did.unittitle: Christmas card, letter from Jos√© Gutierrez, 1940

scopecontent.p: This dismantled notebook includes Hans Hofmann's notes about lectures and theories and is illustrated with diagrams and drawings. Also found are miscellaneous booklets.

did.unittitle: Pages of notes, including Hofmann's theories, displaying 13 diagrams and 4 drawings, 1932
Drawing and 5 booklets concerning artists' materials, 1932-1933
Pages of notes displaying 4 diagrams and a drawing, 1932-1933

scopecontent.p: This series consists of 4 sketchbooks, and hundreds of drawings, collages, and a lithograph that document the development of his unique artistic style. The media of the art work includes pencil, charcoal, conte crayon, pastel, ink, and cardboard strips.
